linkTarget.anchoringText: This value works in many situations but must be corrected for each geologic setting. Since each basin goes through its own consolidation and compaction process's, the density of each basin will vary, and oftentimes the density within the same field will vary (King et al. 2010). A relatively increasing trend of vertical pressure is observed over a north to south direction in the study area. This paper looks to analyze this north to south trend in three main basins. These basins include The North Slope (Colville Basin), The Nenana Basin, and Cook Inlet as shown in Figure 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Alaska Petroleum Basins Overview (Moore and Box 2016). Studied basins are highlighted in red circles.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Alaska Petroleum Basins Overview (Moore and Box 2016). Studied basins are highlighted in red circles.

linkTarget.bib:
Moore et al., 2016
Moore , E. Thomas , Stephen E. Box . 2016. Age, distribution and style of deformation in Alaska north of 60Â°N: Implications for assembly of Alaska (in Tectonophysics 691 , Part A: 133 170 . http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0040195116302323.

linkTarget.anchoringText: As a result of plate collision, the Pacific Plate plunges under the North American Plate almost directly under Cook Inlet. All the petroleum basins examined here are on the North American plate with the North Slope being furthest from the subduction zone, and Cook Inlet Being right on top of it (Figure 2). This subduction zone has led to high numbers of earthquakes, resulting from deformation in this area (Finzel, Flesch, and Ridgway 2011). A brief description of each sedimentary basin is provided next.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Components of a typical ocean/continent subduction zone (USGS 2016), modified from Kious and Tilling (1996)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Components of a typical ocean/continent subduction zone (USGS 2016), modified from Kious and Tilling (1996)

linkTarget.bib: USGS, 2016 USGS. 2016. USGS Open-File Report 00-365, Eastern Aleutian Volcanic Arc Digital Model - Version 1.0.

W. Jacquelyne and I. Tilling, 1996
Kious, W. Jacquelyne , Robert I. Tilling . 1996. This Dynamic Earth (Reprint) .

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Cook Inlet is along the pacific plate boundary as shown in Figure 3 between the Kenai and Chugach mountains. The area has had large amounts of tidal, alluvial and glaciation-fed deposition (Mankemthong and Pavlis 2013, Swenson 1997, Saltus 2011). The basin includes five Miocene formations: the Sterling, Beluga, Tyonek, Hemlock, and West Foreland formations, which are part of a northeast anticline that follows the inlet northeast from the North Pacific Ocean. The formations are non-marine sandstones, siltstones, claystones and shale, and thin toward the edges of the basin (Mankemthong and Pavlis 2013, Swenson 1997).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Major faults of the Cook Inlet and interaction along the plate boundary (Mankemthong and Pavlis 2013)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Major faults of the Cook Inlet and interaction along the plate boundary (Mankemthong and Pavlis 2013)

linkTarget.bib:
Mankemthong et al., 2013
Mankemthong , Niti , Terry Pavlis . 2013. (in Geosphere
9 (2): 18 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fourteen wells were chosen from different fields across 3 major basins in Alaska. These were the Colville Basin (North Slope), Nenana Basin, and the Cook Inlet Basin. Figure 4 shows the location of all of the wells that were chosen for this study.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Location Map of Study Wells in Alaska

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location Map of Study Wells in Alaska

linkTarget.anchoringText: As expected, most of the fields followed trend lines of between 0.9 psi/ft. and 1 psi/ft. at the deeper depths, with more variance in the shallower depths. All the wells analyzed are placed on the Figure 5 to easily see trends in vertical stress and pressure gradient.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Vertical Stress in Alaska vs Depth

formatted-caption.caption-text: Vertical Stress in Alaska vs Depth

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 6 presents the pressure gradients of all the wells sampled. It shows that as the depth of the wells increase the spread of the data decreases.

From this data, MATLAB was used again to generate models to show how the pressure gradients change through Alaska. The first figure is a snapshot of Alaska at a depth of 6000 feet. This figure shows that aside from the OCS and Kugrua wells, there appears to be a very slight North to South trend of increasing overburden. This trend is shown in illustrated in Figure 7.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Overburden Gradient in Alaska at 6000 Feet

formatted-caption.caption-text: Overburden Gradient in Alaska at 6000 Feet

linkTarget.anchoringText: This trend can further be developed by examining overburden gradients at 4 distinct depths as shown in Figure 8. Once again this shows that aside from the OCS and Kugrua wells, there is a slight North to South trend of increasing overburden.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Stress Gradients Across Alaska Wells @ 3000 ft depth @ 6000 ft depth @ 8000 ft depth @ 10,000 ft depth

formatted-caption.caption-text: Stress Gradients Across Alaska Wells @ 3000 ft depth @ 6000 ft depth @ 8000 ft depth @ 10,000 ft depth

linkTarget.anchoringText: Authors believe that this increase in vertical stress is due to the collision of the Pacific and North American Plates. As seen from Figure 9, there have been several earthquakes recorded in Alaska along this subduction zone. This subduction zone is suspected to be resulted in stress in the formations resulting in higher vertical stresses. For variances in the data, this is attributed to the high deformation zones that exist on the North American plate. High deformation zones can cause fractures which will decrease formation density and change vertical stress.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Highlight of Earthquakes in Alaska along Pacific and North American Plates

formatted-caption.caption-text: Highlight of Earthquakes in Alaska along Pacific and North American Plates
